 Obviously, we got our Beatles, Stones, Pink Floyd, Zepplin, U2 (those guys are shoe - in's.) Here is an article I stumbled across that rates the top 10 bands of all times.
 
 Top ten bands  
 
 I can respect the opinion this article with exception of #5 and #10. But that's just me.  There is a BIG gap between the top three and the others below.

 I absolutely ADORE U2. Live they are fun. They are Irish. They are cute as heck. They have heart. They have staying power. Their strengths are in an ability to experiment well - Bono's awesome vocals - and the poetry.
 
 That said - you are correct in that musically they have not shaken things up too much. 
 
 The Ramones are another story. They still inspire. Yes they are simple - they play the nuts and guts and skeletal structure of rock and roll at it's purest. Fancy guitar and and experimental sound are window dressing without the drive of the rock's heartbeat - and that is what the Ramones did oh so well.
 
 What is the full list in the article anyway? I could only get to like #4.
 
 How can your list have three Pink Floyd's and no Led Zeppelin's. That is just wrong, man. :p

Liminus

No particular order...
 
 1. Pearl Jam - amazing variety of songs, from both an emotional and stylistic point of view, combined with awesome talent on the guitar (Mike McCready) and drums (latest and seemingly now permanent drummer, ex-Soundgarden Matt Cameron) and vocals (Mr Vedder himself). What I love about their songs is that even though the lyrics can be obscure at times, they are all essentially stories, which gives them their emotional impact. Although I've never seen them live, I have 3 live recordings which reveal their ability to only ever improve on their studio CDs when they are on stage. Spellbinding.
 
 2. Devin Townsend Band - like nothing else I've ever listened to, the Dev manages to create some of the most awe-inspiring, beautiful, yet at times bone-crunchingly heavy music you can imagine. Imagine a monstrous Metallica epic, add an orchestra and a plethora of sythesised effects, and imagine it somehow not seeming cheesy, overblown or pretentious because of the obvious sense of humour and enjoyment, sheer indulgence in being able to create such powerful music. And I'm only talking about the 3rd and 4th albums here, the 1st being a weird, dark embryonic version of the later material, and the 2nd, Infinity, should be in everyone's collection as it is an amalgamation of every style of Western music you can imagine, chopped up and put through a blender by a madman. There is so much talent in this band it's hard to believe.
 
 3. Tool - again, like nothing else I've ever listened to. Dark and brooding without being over-the-top or self-pitying, Tool do passion and anger like no-one else; even on the hundredth listen to the title track from their latest offering, Lateralus, it's impossible not to get lost in the song. It just reaches right into your head and heart with no resistance and makes your emotions follow it all the way to the piledriving climax. Authority. That's what Tool have. You just have to sit up and take notice. Combine this hard-to-define musical aspect with unbelievable songwriting ability, rhythmic complexity and at times ambiguity, and Maynard's haunting voice and you have something that you have to call 'metal', but which is in fact just out there on its own. Tool are the Pink Floyd of the 21st century.
 
 4. Hendrix - Obviously. While there are plenty of bands from the 50s, 60s and 70s I could name, who have all produced a vast catalogue of classic music and been indispensably influential, Hendrix's guitar style changed everything and I listen to him far more than I do Sabbath, Zep, Stones, Clapton, Bowie, Eagles or Floyd because you just can't help but enjoy the combination of measureless talent, passion and sheer love of making music on every song.
 
 5. The White Stripes - another band that sound like no-one else. With their roots firmly in the country and western tradition, they have come up with an amazing stylistic variety whilst still retaining that c&w feel, especially on their new album. I was never a fan until Glastonbury this year, thought I'd check them out on the Pyramid Stage and was absolutely entranced for the best part of 90 minutes. The most impressive things about them are the sound they produce on CD and their commanding stage presence, between just two people.

The thing is, I've tried to like the Beatles; I've even got their entire back catalogue on my PC, but it's just so dull.
 I realise that at the time a lot of their songs were innovative and exciting, but I think maybe the fact that they've influenced so much of the modern Western music tradition makes them sound cliched even though they were the ones inventing those 'cliches' at the time.
 OK, there are a few songs I like: Hey Jude, Let It Be, Magical Mystery Tour, Dear Prudence and It's All Too Much. But that's it I'm afraid. The rest just bore me. 
 Partly I think it's Paul McCartney's voice, he just sounds like such a whining little turd, and John Lennon just annoys me..."Imagine all the people, living out their boring, perfect, idealised, unachievable existence, yoo-hoo, ooo-ooo". And a 'bed-in' or whatever they called it? What did that achieve? World Peace? You'd have more chance of getting a blow job from the Pope.

NICKELBACK!???? 
 
 They are the only band I ever bought a ticket for and walked out on (this was before they had any hits here - I just knew the name as I am pretty in tune with the Canadian scene). Strumming chords and whining - they are absolutely terrible. When did rock turn into a melodrama? I couldn't believe it when they made it big. I want killer guitar riffs and funky basslines. 
 
 I have also had the misfortune of running into Kroeger's ego at a club in BC. Not that that moment formed this opinion, I already hated his band. He was so loud and obnoxious - freakin drunk Alberta farm boy with his Michael Bolton hair.
 
 Gag.
 
 You will have to forgive my rant. The Nickelback thing really bugs me. Most of my friends are musicians. I know bands in Canada that Nickelback cut their teeth opening for, who were better, and sweated ten times harder for a hell of a lot longer and got missed. But it's all about the cash flow so we are force fed a million Brittneys and Pear Jam wannabes (Creed, Nickelback) - now it's Green Day wannabes. I love both Pearl Jam and Green Day, but who needs a thousand copy-cats? Hearing a new sound (like the White Stripes for example - and I had the MTV beat on them by two years) is a rarity. I rarely turn on the radio anymore. I can try a dozen stations - and 90% of the time it's garbage - and when it's not it's either classic stuff or a little college station with barely any bandwidth. Nickelback sort of represent to me everything that is wrong with the music industry today. I am convinced that if a phenomenon like Zeppelin were to happen today - we would all miss out because the XXXXXX at Disney, Viacom and Clear Channel wouldn't know talent if you stuck up their collective rear and set it on fire.

Big_Bear_Scot

My top five.
 
 1. The Who
 2. Cream
 3. Led Zep
 4. The Jam
 5. Stone Roses
 
 I am really a fan of rock music, with the only exceptions(in my top 5) being the Stones Roses who melded rock and dance music to create an unique sound. They only produced Two albums but their influence can still be heard in the British Music scene today with bands like Oasis, Kaiser Cheifs and Kasbain.
 
 The Jam where a band that came out during the punk era, they tended to be part of the same scene but their influences where much different. They harked back to the days of the Mods in the 60s and like those mods they where influenced by Motown and Northern Soul. The early Jam records where very much like punk albums but as the band evolved you could hear the influence of Northern Soul in records like Town Called Malice and Beat Surrender.
 
 I guess most people have heard of Led Zeppelin so I will not say much about them except that they ROCK emoticon_xgood 
 
 Cream where a 60s band that could be called the first Rock super group, it consisted of Eric Clapton on Guitar and vocal, Jack Bruce on Base and Vocals and Ginger Baker on drums. They produced music that was a mix of jazz and blues with heavier guitars of course. In my opinion they practically invented Heavy Rock music and if you listen to any Heavy Rock band such as Led Zeppelin you can clearly hear the influence of Cream. 
 
 The Who don't need any introduce just suffice it to say that they where a band(and still are to a certain extent) that had the perfect blend of musicians.

I'm sure most of you disagree with this. In no particular order:
 [*]Death[*]Children of Bodom[*]Slayer[*]Overkill[*]Deicide

 
 I was hoping to find another metal fan here. I can't say much about overkill and deicide as I am unfamiliar with them. But death, bodom, and slayer XXXXing rock. How do you feel about Possessed, Machine Head, or In Flames?
 
 With that said my list is kind of eclectic.
 
 1. Opeth-beautiful and brutal
 2. Pink Floyd-apparently I'm not alone on this one
 3. Led Zeppelin-heaviest blues ever
 4. Queen-led zep meets yes
 5. Parliament-sometimes ya gotta swing
 
 As far as artists go
 
 1. Buckethead-most creative and inventive guitarist I've heard
 2. Devin Townsend-didn't want to list just his band and strapping; everything he touches is golden
 3. Santana-inspired me to play guitar; Him and Brian May...if only I could play like either of them
 4. Prince-he's responsible for my birth so I guess I owe him one; you probably do too
 5. Billie Holiday-one the most raw and natural performers

I was hoping to find another metal fan here. I can't say much about overkill and deicide as I am unfamiliar with them. But death, bodom, and slayer XXXXing rock. How do you feel about Possessed, Machine Head, or In Flames?
 
 
 

 With that said my list is kind of eclectic.
 
 1. Opeth-beautiful and brutal
 2. Pink Floyd-apparently I'm not alone on this one
 3. Led Zeppelin-heaviest blues ever
 4. Queen-led zep meets yes
 5. Parliament-sometimes ya gotta swing
 
 As far as artists go
 
 1. Buckethead-most creative and inventive guitarist I've heard
 2. Devin Townsend-didn't want to list just his band and strapping; everything he touches is golden
 3. Santana-inspired me to play guitar; Him and Brian May...if only I could play like either of them
 4. Prince-he's responsible for my birth so I guess I owe him one; you probably do too
 5. Billie Holiday-one the most raw and natural performers

 

 
 I'm not very familiar with any of them. I've heard about MOST of them them, but I've never listened to any of them (except Buckethead and Opeth).
 
 Just every Metal band I listen to without thinking very hard, so I may have left a few bands out. These aren't all the bands I've heard of, just the ones I listen to. 
 
 Non-Death:[*]older stuff by Metallica[*]Megadeth[*]Slayer[*]Overkill[*]Motorhead[*]Iron Maiden[*]Candlemass[*]Acid King (technically Stoner Doom)[*]Opeth[*]Shrinebuilder
 Death Metal:[*]Skinless[*]Suffocation[*]Nile[*]Morbid Angel[*]Cannibal Corpse[*]Cannabis Corpse[*]Six Feet Under[*]Deicide[*]Death[*]Amon Amarth[*]some stuff by Children of Bodom[*]Goatwhore (blackened Death Metal)[*]Demilich
 Grind:[*]Agoraphobic Nosebleed[*]Pig Destroyer
 I don't need to make a list for black Metal, since Gorgoroth is the only Black Metal band I'm familiar with. I also don't need a list for Avant-Garde metal, since Meshuggah is the only AGM band I've found that I think is worth listening to.
 
 I don't have the biggest list of bands but I'm not ashamed of it. Despite what alot of fans seem to think, being a Metalhead isn't a competition to see who knows more underground bands than everyone else. I didn't even mention any bands that are underground, per se.
COBHC
